title: Computer Networks - MODERATE Level
description: üö¶ Navigate the network stack! This quiz focuses on the $\mathbf{OSI}$ and $\mathbf{TCP/IP}$ models, **routing** üó∫Ô∏è, $\text{port \, numbers}$ üö™, and methods for $\mathbf{error \, detection}$ and $\text{reliable \, transfer}$. (20 Questions - 40 Minutes)

questions.text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for **routing**?
What is the port number for HTTP?
Which protocol provides **reliable** data transfer?
The $\mathbf{ARP}$ (Address Resolution Protocol) maps which two addresses?
In a subnet mask like 255.255.255.0, what does the '255' represent?

options.a: The host portion of the address
options.b: The network portion of the address

questions.text: Which layer of the OSI model is responsible for $\mathbf{segmentation}$ and $\mathbf{reassembly}$ of data?
What is the purpose of the $\mathbf{Three-Way \, Handshake}$ in TCP?
Which $\mathbf{routing \, algorithm}$ uses the number of hops as the metric?
What does $\mathbf{NAT}$ (Network Address Translation) allow a network to do?

options.b: Translate private IP addresses to a single public IP address

questions.text: The maximum number of hops a packet can traverse before being discarded is controlled by which field in the IP header?
The difference between a **Hub** and a **Switch** is that a Switch operates at the Data Link layer and...

options.c: Forwards frames based on MAC addresses

questions.text: Which class of IPv4 addresses is intended for multicasting?
What is the primary function of the $\mathbf{Cyclic \, Redundancy \, Check \, (CRC)}$?
Which error control mechanism is used by TCP to handle lost segments?
The $\mathbf{payload}$ of a TCP segment is passed up to which layer of the TCP/IP model?
In $\mathbf{full-duplex}$ communication, data flows...

options.b: In both directions, but not simultaneously

questions.text: The primary role of $\mathbf{ICMP}$ (Internet Control Message Protocol) is for...

options.b: Error reporting and network diagnostics (e.g., ping)

questions.text: What is the term for the process of dividing a large network into smaller, more manageable sub-networks?
Which protocol does $\mathbf{Telnet}$ use for remote terminal access?
The $\mathbf{window \, size}$ in TCP primarily controls...

options.b: The amount of data that can be sent before an acknowledgment is required (Flow Control)
